shortdesc.p: Get started creating and managing your tests with TestArchitect by reviewing these introductory lessons.

shortdesc.p: Here you'll learn some of the key components of and Action-Based Testing, and take a first lesson on creating a test.

topic.title: Part 2: Becoming a TestArchitect power user

In some special cases, however – such as testing on certain platforms, or having TestArchitect integrated with third-party tools – additional software requirements apply.

shortdesc.p: In some cases, you may need to install TestArchitect in silent mode. In this mode, the installation is performed automatically without any user interaction.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In some cases, you may need to install TestArchitect in silent mode. In this mode, the installation is performed automatically without any user interaction.

shortdesc.p: To install TestArchitect in silent mode by using InstallShield, create an installation response file to store the needed installation settings.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To install TestArchitect in silent mode by using InstallShield, create an installation response file to store the needed installation settings.

shortdesc.p: Deploying TestArchitect installation file on other computers and running the installation there using the created response file.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Deploying TestArchitect installation file on other computers and running the installation there using the created response file.

shortdesc.p: In silent mode, the installation wizard shows no informative, warning or error messages. The installation program creates the log file and writes the installation status to that file. You can examine that log file to learn whether TestArchitect has been installed successfully.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In silent mode, the installation wizard shows no informative, warning or error messages. The installation program creates the log file and writes the installation status to that file. You can examine that log file to learn whether TestArchitect has been installed successfully.

shortdesc.p: In some cases, you may need to uninstall the current version of TestArchitect in silent mode before installing the newer version. In this mode, the uninstallation is performed automatically without any user interaction.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In some cases, you may need to uninstall the current version of TestArchitect in silent mode before installing the newer version. In this mode, the uninstallation is performed automatically without any user interaction.

shortdesc.p: To remove previously installed TestArchitect in silent mode by using InstallShield, create an uninstallation response file to store the needed uninstallation settings.

shortdesc.p: In silent mode, the uninstallation wizard shows no informative, warning or error messages. The uninstallation program creates the log file and writes the uninstallation status to that file. You can examine that log file to learn whether TestArchitect has been removed successfully.

In silent mode, the uninstallation wizard shows no informative, warning or error messages. The uninstallation program creates the log file and writes the uninstallation status to that file. You can examine that log file to learn whether

topic.title: Using batch file to automate silent installation

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect has a number of search commands available. You can find an item in the explorer tree, or a text string in files like test modules or action definitions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect has a number of search commands available. You can find an item in the explorer tree, or a text string in files like test modules or action definitions.

topic.title: Searching items in the TestArchitect explorer tree

shortdesc.p: A search is conducted within a subtree of a project. The search is restricted to one particular item type (test module, action, data set or interface entity, etc.), and is limited to item names (not item contents or metadata).

topicmeta.navtitle: Searching items in the TestArchitect explorer tree
topicmeta.linktext: Searching items in the TestArchitect explorer tree
topicmeta.shortdesc: A search is conducted within a subtree of a project. The search is restricted to one particular item type (test module, action, data set or interface entity, etc.), and is limited to item names (not item contents or metadata).

shortdesc.p: In addition to item names, you can conduct searches of the text content of test modules, user-defined actions, data sets and interface entities.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In addition to item names, you can conduct searches of the text content of test modules, user-defined actions, data sets and interface entities.

shortdesc.p: Custom actions require complete documentation to ensure correct usage.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Custom actions require complete documentation to ensure correct usage.

shortdesc.p: To make use of Help-system extensibility for custom actions, you must modify the mapping file user_defined_help.ini, along with the corresponding commands.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To make use of Help-system extensibility for custom actions, you must modify the mapping file user_defined_help.ini, along with the corresponding commands.

shortdesc.p: The primary value of the Help System Extensibility feature is in allowing you to provide reference pages documenting your custom actions. Context-sensitive help functionality allows you to offer testers and automation engineers easy access to the actions' definitions and application notes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The primary value of the Help System Extensibility feature is in allowing you to provide reference pages documenting your custom actions. Context-sensitive help functionality allows you to offer testers and automation engineers easy access to the actions' definitions and application notes.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect Client can be configured to your requirements with a large collection of customizable features.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect maintains a history list of your recently viewed project items such as test modules, actions and data sets, and lets you access that list to conveniently reopen those items in the editor.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect maintains a history list of your recently viewed project items such as test modules, actions and data sets, and lets you access that list to conveniently reopen those items in the editor.

shortdesc.p: Within a given session, TestArchitect Client keeps track of the tabs you have closed and provides you with a convenient means to reopen your recently closed tabs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Within a given session, TestArchitect Client keeps track of the tabs you have closed and provides you with a convenient means to reopen your recently closed tabs.

shortdesc.p: Keep track of TestArchitect project items which you visit frequently by storing them as favorites.

shortdesc.p: You can open your favorite items from the toolbar or from the Favorites list view.

shortdesc.p: Within a TestArchitect repository, unique URLs are automatically assigned to various project items. This allows hyperlinks to be embedded into documents, such as spreadsheets, presentations, and word processing documents.

p.span: TestArchitect provides you with a worksheet-like test editor to let you view, create and modify action-based tests.

shortdesc.ph: TestArchitect provides you with a worksheet-like test editor to let you view, create and modify action-based tests.

shortdesc.p: Use Content Assist in the test editor to complete your action lines faster and with more accuracy.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Use Content Assist in the test editor to complete your action lines faster and with more accuracy.

shortdesc.p: As you edit your tests, you often find yourself needing to know which actions can be used for a given control or window. Content Assist's applicable actions list provides you with a convenient means of viewing and selecting from the list of actions available for a given UI element.

topicmeta.linktext: Applicable action suggestions for a window or control
topicmeta.shortdesc: As you edit your tests, you often find yourself needing to know which actions can be used for a given control or window. Content Assist's applicable actions list provides you with a convenient means of viewing and selecting from the list of actions available for a given UI element.

shortdesc.p: For any set of controls whose TA class is user-defined, you can specify the list of actions that apply. This list will then appear in the applicable actions list of the Content Assist window when you work with these controls in the test editor.

topicmeta.linktext: Specifying action suggestion for a control belonging to a user-defined TA class
topicmeta.shortdesc: For any set of controls whose TA class is user-defined, you can specify the list of actions that apply. This list will then appear in the applicable actions list of the Content Assist window when you work with these controls in the test editor.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect's Go to Definition feature enables you to navigate instantaneously to an item from a reference to it in the test editor.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect's Go to Definition feature enables you to navigate instantaneously to an item from a reference to it in the test editor.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect supports automated testing of web applications on Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Safari, and Microsoft Edge. shortdesc.p: A project consists of a collection of items called project items. TestArchitect has the facility to view, create, edit, manage, and, in the case of tests modules and actions, execute, project items.

topicmeta.shortdesc:
A project consists of a collection of items called project items.
TestArchitect has the facility to view, create, edit, manage, and, in the case of tests modules and actions, execute, project items.

shortdesc.p: A TestArchitect project is a container for all assets required for your testing efforts relating to a specific project. A project is included in a repository, and may coexist with other projects in that repository.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A TestArchitect project is a container for all assets required for your testing efforts relating to a specific project. A project is included in a repository, and may coexist with other projects in that repository.

shortdesc.p: Deleting a project removes the entire project, including actions, tests, data, results, etc., from the repository.

shortdesc.p: Renaming a project only changes the project's name and not its content.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Renaming a project only changes the project's name and not its content.

shortdesc.p: You can quickly display the latest test result for a project from the project's context menu.

p.span: Project subscription aids in large-scale, complex test development. Tests distributed over multiple projects are allowed to share actions, interface definitions, data sets, and picture checks. (Note that, in the case of picture checks, only shared picture checks can be subscribed to.)

shortdesc.ph:
Project subscription aids in large-scale, complex test development. Tests distributed over multiple projects are allowed to share actions, interface definitions, data sets, and picture checks. (Note that, in the case of picture checks, only
shared picture checks can be subscribed to.)

p.span: By subscribing to other projects, you can avoid duplication of effort and allow your project to avail itself of the actions, data sets, interface definitions and picture checks that already reside in those projects.

shortdesc.ph: By subscribing to other projects, you can avoid duplication of effort and allow your project to avail itself of the actions, data sets, interface definitions and picture checks that already reside in those projects.

p.span: TestArchitect employs a depth-first search (DFS) algorithm to locate, among subscribed projects, the definitions for actions, interface entities, interface elements, data sets, and picture checks.

shortdesc.ph: TestArchitect employs a depth-first search (DFS) algorithm to locate, among subscribed projects, the definitions for actions, interface entities, interface elements, data sets, and picture checks.

shortdesc.p: After creating a project, adding necessary test modules, and defining relevant actions and interfaces for those test modules, you are ready to execute the project’s test modules.

topicmeta.shortdesc: After creating a project, adding necessary test modules, and defining relevant actions and interfaces for those test modules, you are ready to execute the project’s test modules.

shortdesc.p: You can restrict access to a project by granting permissions to selected users.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can restrict access to a project by granting permissions to selected users.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect searches the entire project and returns all tokens matching the searched items.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect searches the entire project and returns all tokens matching the searched items.

shortdesc.p: Reports can be created for the entire project or a subtree of the project.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reports can be created for the entire project or a subtree of the project.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect has the facility to manage, control, view and edit project items.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect has the facility to manage, control, view and edit project items.

shortdesc.p: Tests in TestArchitect are centered around test modules. In a project, test modules of a similar nature can be are organized into a test folder. Test modules inside a test folder can be further organized into subfolders.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Tests in TestArchitect are centered around test modules. In a project, test modules of a similar nature can be are organized into a test folder. Test modules inside a test folder can be further organized into subfolders.

shortdesc.p: Data sets contain rows of values that can be executed retrieved by a test and acted on sequentially.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Data sets contain rows of values that can be executed retrieved by a test and acted on sequentially.

shortdesc.p: You can create a data set using the New Data Set dialog box.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can create a data set using the New Data Set dialog box.

shortdesc.p: Data sets are used to provide values for a sequence of action lines. To start such a sequence from within a test, use the use data set action.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Data sets are used to provide values for a sequence of action lines. To start such a sequence from within a test, use the use data set action.

shortdesc.p: Data sets can be exported to archive files (.ZIP format), which can be used as a backup or for re-importing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Data sets can be exported to archive files ( .ZIP format), which can be used as a backup or for re-importing.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect lets you easily import a data set archive file (.ZIP format) into a TestArchitect data set.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect lets you easily import a data set archive file ( .ZIP format) into a TestArchitect data set.

shortdesc.p: In some cases you may want to use values from an external data source to supply your action lines with data vectors.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In some cases you may want to use values from an external data source to supply your action lines with data vectors.

topic.title: Copying and pasting data set values

shortdesc.p: One means of contributing data values to a data set is by pasting them in, using the traditional copy-and-paste technique. The source of such values can be another application (for example, Microsoft Excel™, MS Word™, or Notepad) or another item in the TestArchitect editor itself. The copied data may be pasted into the grid of data set items as either raw data or data set values.

topicmeta.navtitle: Copying and pasting data set values
topicmeta.linktext: Copying and pasting data set values
topicmeta.shortdesc: One means of contributing data values to a data set is by pasting them in, using the traditional copy-and-paste technique. The source of such values can be another application (for example, Microsoft Excel, MS Word, or Notepad) or another item in the TestArchitect editor itself. The copied data may be pasted into the grid of data set items as either raw data or data set values.

shortdesc.p: A test suite is a collection of test modules of a project. Test modules organized into a given test suite usually have some common feature for which it makes sense to have them grouped together, generally for execution purposes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A test suite is a collection of test modules of a project. Test modules organized into a given test suite usually have some common feature for which it makes sense to have them grouped together, generally for execution purposes.

shortdesc.p: A static test suite is a collection of test modules that are grouped manually for test execution purposes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A static test suite is a collection of test modules that are grouped manually for test execution purposes.

shortdesc.p: How to create a static test suite and assign member test modules to it.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to create a static test suite and assign member test modules to it.

shortdesc.p: How to add test modules to an existing static test suite.

topicmeta.navtitle: Adding new test modules to a static test suite
topicmeta.linktext: Adding new test modules to a static test suite
topicmeta.shortdesc: How to add test modules to an existing static test suite.

shortdesc.p: You can reorder the execution of test modules in a static test suite.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can reorder the execution of test modules in a static test suite.

shortdesc.p: A dynamic test suite is a collection of test modules whose membership is determined dynamically, based on the criteria specified in an associated data profile.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A dynamic test suite is a collection of test modules whose membership is determined dynamically, based on the criteria specified in an associated data profile.

shortdesc.p: You can create a dynamic test suite based on the following data profile types: test module, test case, test objective, test result, or test case result.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can create a dynamic test suite based on the following data profile types: test module, test case, test objective, test result, or test case result.

topic.title: Adding new test modules to a dynamic test suite

shortdesc.p: New test modules in a dynamic test suite can be added only by customizing the test suite's data profile.

topicmeta.linktext: Adding new test modules to a dynamic test suite
topicmeta.shortdesc: New test modules in a dynamic test suite can be added only by customizing the test suite's data profile.

topic.title: Rearranging test modules in a dynamic test suite

shortdesc.p: Test modules in a dynamic test suite can be reordered only by customizing the dynamic test suite's data profile.

topicmeta.navtitle: Rearranging test modules in a dynamic test suite
topicmeta.linktext: Rearranging test modules in a dynamic test suite
topicmeta.shortdesc: Test modules in a dynamic test suite can be reordered only by customizing the dynamic test suite's data profile.

topic.title: Moving test suites, test suite folders, and modules

shortdesc.p: Static and dynamic test suites, test suite folders, and modules within the same project can be moved and copied around the TestArchitect explorer tree.

topicmeta.navtitle: Moving test suites, test suite folders, and modules
topicmeta.linktext: Moving test suites, test suite folders, and modules

Static and dynamic test suites, test suite folders, and modules within the same project can be moved and copied around the
TestArchitect explorer tree.

shortdesc.p: Both static test suites and dynamic test suites can be executed from the Execute Test dialog box.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Both static test suites and dynamic test suites can be executed from the Execute Test dialog box.

shortdesc.p: A bug in TestArchitect is a failure in an automation run which impairs or prevents the proper functioning of the automated test, and which can generally be attributed either to a bug in the application under test, or to a problem with the test itself. From hereon, any such bug is referred to as a TestArchitect bug, or TA bug.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A bug in TestArchitect is a failure in an automation run which impairs or prevents the proper functioning of the automated test, and which can generally be attributed either to a bug in the application under test, or to a problem with the test itself. From hereon, any such bug is referred to as a TestArchitect bug, or TA bug.

shortdesc.p: An unregistered TestArchitect bug (TA bug) is one that is created in TestArchitect but it is not associated with a JIRA bug.

topicmeta.shortdesc: An unregistered TestArchitect bug (TA bug) is one that is created in TestArchitect but it is not associated with a JIRA bug.

shortdesc.p: Known bugs indicate where fails in a test have been recognized so that those fails are ignored in subsequent automation run results. The Ignore known bug feature helps you obtain test results from test runs that are not cluttered up with fails from known bugs, thus rendering the results easier to analyze.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Known bugs indicate where fails in a test have been recognized so that those fails are ignored in subsequent automation run results. The Ignore known bug feature helps you obtain test results from test runs that are not cluttered up with fails from known bugs, thus rendering the results easier to analyze.

shortdesc.p: Known bugs in a test may be flagged, or marked. Marking known bugs allows the fails associated with the bugs to be ignored, so that they are not counted in test results.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Known bugs in a test may be flagged, or marked. Marking known bugs allows the fails associated with the bugs to be ignored, so that they are not counted in test results.

topic.title: Reviewing test results with known bugs

shortdesc.p: Reviewing test results can assist you in determining if and when JIRA bug issues on a JIRA server should be closed.

topicmeta.navtitle: Reviewing test results with known bugs
topicmeta.linktext: Reviewing test results with known bugs
topicmeta.shortdesc: Reviewing test results can assist you in determining if and when JIRA bug issues on a JIRA server should be closed.

shortdesc.p: Removed known bug marks from action lines when they are no longer needed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Removed known bug marks from action lines when they are no longer needed.

topic.title: Viewing bugs related to a test module or test case

shortdesc.p: If an action line in a test module is marked with a TA bug, the parent test case and test module are also marked with that TA bug. You have option to view all the TA bugs which are exposed by the parent test modules/test cases.

topicmeta.navtitle: Viewing bugs related to a test module or test case
topicmeta.linktext: Viewing bugs related to a test module or test case
topicmeta.shortdesc: If an action line in a test module is marked with a TA bug, the parent test case and test module are also marked with that TA bug. You have option to view all the TA bugs which are exposed by the parent test modules/test cases.

shortdesc.p: How to access existing TA bugs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to access existing TA bugs.

shortdesc.p: TA bugs can be removed from the system once they have been addressed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TA bugs can be removed from the system once they have been addressed.

shortdesc.p: Revision control is the process used to track and control changes made to project items in a repository. Changes to an item are identified by its revision timestamp (which includes date and time accurate to a small fraction of a second), the user making the changes, and other information, when the item is checked in.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Revision control is the process used to track and control changes made to project items in a repository. Changes to an item are identified by its revision timestamp (which includes date and time accurate to a small fraction of a second), the user making the changes, and other information, when the item is checked in.

shortdesc.p: Check-in is a process of writing the changes made to the local working copy of a file back into the repository.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Check-in is a process of writing the changes made to the local working copy of a file back into the repository.

shortdesc.p: Check-out is the process of creating a local working copy from the repository.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Check-out is the process of creating a local working copy from the repository.

shortdesc.p: Undoing checkout allows you discard any changes you have made to local copies of project items and check them back in to the repository.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Undoing checkout allows you discard any changes you have made to local copies of project items and check them back in to the repository.

shortdesc.p: The TestArchitect repository saves pertinent information on a project item every time the item is checked in. This includes timestamp, assigned version, project name, item type (test modules, data sets, actions, etc.), item name, user who checked in the item, and included comments.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The TestArchitect repository saves pertinent information on a project item every time the item is checked in. This includes timestamp, assigned version, project name, item type (test modules, data sets, actions, etc.), item name, user who checked in the item, and included comments.

shortdesc.p: The rollback feature restores the status of an older checked in revision of any project item to the current working revision.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The rollback feature restores the status of an older checked in revision of any project item to the current working revision.

shortdesc.p: You can select a checked in revision of any project item to view its history from the Revision History dialog box.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can select a checked in revision of any project item to view its history from the Revision History dialog box.

shortdesc.p: How to view the differences between two historical revisions of a project item.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to view the differences between two historical revisions of a project item.

shortdesc.p: Renaming History stores all records of name changes made to specific project items.

shortdesc.p: To simplify test creation, TestArchitect includes the Action Recorder, a tool which records your manual operations on the application under test, captures the resulting screen output, automatically generates keyword action lines, and writes the action lines to your test. The recorded action lines can then be replayed during automation to simulate user actions against the application under test.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To simplify test creation, TestArchitect includes the Action Recorder, a tool which records your manual operations on the application under test, captures the resulting screen output, automatically generates keyword action lines, and writes the action lines to your test. The recorded action lines can then be replayed during automation to simulate user actions against the application under test.

shortdesc.p: This topic provides general information on the Action Recorder's recording functionality and controls.

shortdesc.p: The process of how to capture an application's interface information, how to select only those parts of it that you require for your project, and how to rename the elements of the interface to make them easier to work with.

shortdesc.p: Interface mapping identifies elements of an interface in an application under test

topicmeta.shortdesc: Interface mapping identifies elements of an interface in an application under test

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect interfaces are implemented with interface entities and interface elements. These project items identify the windows and controls of an application's user interface, and assign TA names to them.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect interfaces are implemented with interface entities and interface elements. These project items identify the windows and controls of an application's user interface, and assign TA names to them.

shortdesc.p: An interface in TestArchitect is essentially a container for a set of interface entities and elements, which perform the actual mappings.

topicmeta.shortdesc: An interface in TestArchitect is essentially a container for a set of interface entities and elements, which perform the actual mappings.

shortdesc.p: The default interface in a project is the one that is in effect during a test if no other interface has been specified for the test. (Typically, however, a test initializes itself with the use interface built-in action to specify the interface to be used).

topicmeta.shortdesc: The default interface in a project is the one that is in effect during a test if no other interface has been specified for the test. (Typically, however, a test initializes itself with the use interface built-in action to specify the interface to be used).

shortdesc.p: How to create an interface entity, which is used to represent such AUT elements as desktop windows, browser windows, and dialog boxes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to create an interface entity, which is used to represent such AUT elements as desktop windows, browser windows, and dialog boxes.

shortdesc.p: In addition to the Interface Viewer, TestArchitect offers some handy tools for working with interfaces, or examining the elements of an AUT's user interface.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In addition to the Interface Viewer, TestArchitect offers some handy tools for working with interfaces, or examining the elements of an AUT's user interface.

shortdesc.p: An interface entity consists of a number of interface elements, each of which uses one or more property-value pairs to identify a control of an application window.

topicmeta.shortdesc: An interface entity consists of a number of interface elements, each of which uses one or more property-value pairs to identify a control of an application window.

shortdesc.p: Point-to-identify tool allows you to quickly and conveniently map controls. From within TestArchitect Client, point-to-identify tool is activated by the Identify on the toolbar.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Point-to-identify tool allows you to quickly and conveniently map controls. From within TestArchitect Client, point-to-identify tool is activated by the Identify on the toolbar.

shortdesc.p: You can use client-side point-to-identify in a non-contextual mode, meaning that you use it without the benefit of an existing interface entity as a reference. Use non-contextual point-to-identify to investigate a window or control's properties, or to generate a new interface element for a control.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can use client-side point-to-identify in a non-contextual mode, meaning that you use it without the benefit of an existing interface entity as a reference. Use non-contextual point-to-identify to investigate a window or control's properties, or to generate a new interface element for a control.

topic.title: Using point-to-identify from the context of an interface element

shortdesc.p: Client-side point-to-identify is a handy tool to allow you to modify interface elements, whether to remap a TA name to a new control, or to select a new set of property-value identifiers for it. In these cases, you would use point-to-identify in a contextual mode, in that an existing interface entity is used as a reference point.

topic.title: Naming actions or test modules on the fly

shortdesc.p: The Highlight button functionality within TestArchitect Client is nearly identical to that of the Interface Viewer, except that the context is provided by the interface-related nodes of the TestArchitect explorer tree.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Highlight button functionality within TestArchitect Client is nearly identical to that of the Interface Viewer, except that the context is provided by the interface-related nodes of the TestArchitect explorer tree.

shortdesc.p: The Interface Viewer is a powerful support tool that allows you to capture and save all or parts of an interface definition, and to explore the elements of an AUT's interface.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Launching the Interface Viewer tool.

shortdesc.p: Understanding the information displayed in the Interface Viewer's panels.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Understanding the information displayed in the Interface Viewer's panels.

shortdesc.p: Upon startup, the Interface Viewer takes inventory of every open window in the system on which it is pointed, and displays each one as a node in its UI Explorer tree.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Upon startup, the Interface Viewer takes inventory of every open window in the system on which it is pointed, and displays each one as a node in its UI Explorer tree.

shortdesc.p: The Properties panel displays the properties and property values of the currently-selected window or control node in the UI Explorer panel.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Properties panel displays the properties and property values of the currently-selected window or control node in the UI Explorer panel.

shortdesc.p: The Interface Elements panel displays the interface elements of the open interface entity.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Interface Elements panel displays the interface elements of the open interface entity.

p.span: This panel displays the differences between the defined property values in the interface element and the actual (just-captured) values of those properties in the corresponding control, allowing you to understand why that interface element is no longer able to identify the control.

shortdesc.ph: This panel displays the differences between the defined property values in the interface element and the actual (just-captured) values of those properties in the corresponding control, allowing you to understand why that interface element is no longer able to identify the control.

shortdesc.p: The Interface Viewer incorporates a number of functions into its toolbar.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Interface Viewer incorporates a number of functions into its toolbar.

shortdesc.p: Capturing interface definitions means writing out interface entities with a) mappings of controls to TA names, and b) mapping of windows to interface entities.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Capturing interface definitions means writing out interface entities with a) mappings of controls to TA names, and b) mapping of windows to interface entities.

shortdesc.p: Choosing good logical names is an essential step in the design of your automation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Choosing good logical names is an essential step in the design of your automation.

shortdesc.p: As an application under test evolves over time, its windows and dialog boxes also change; therefore the TestArchitect interface entities associated with them must be updated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: As an application under test evolves over time, its windows and dialog boxes also change; therefore the TestArchitect interface entities associated with them must be updated.

shortdesc.p: Interface elements identify controls in an application window. It is possible, often as a result of an application change, for an interface element to lose its mapping to its associated control. We call this an "unmatched" element, and the cause is generally a change in one or more property values of the control. When this occurs, you must remap the control to the unmatched element.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Interface elements identify controls in an application window. It is possible, often as a result of an application change, for an interface element to lose its mapping to its associated control. We call this an "unmatched" element, and the cause is generally a change in one or more property values of the control. When this occurs, you must remap the control to the unmatched element.

shortdesc.p: The Interface Viewer provides a few means of assisting you in relating nodes on the GUI Element Tree to actual physical items, and vice-versa.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Interface Viewer provides a few means of assisting you in relating nodes on the GUI Element Tree to actual physical items, and vice-versa.

shortdesc.p: When using the Interface Viewer to explore a complex window with many layers of controls, it is sometimes difficult to locate the UI explorer tree node corresponding to a given physical control. The point-to-identify feature, invoked via the Identify button on the Viewer's toolbar, simplifies this process.

topicmeta.shortdesc: When using the Interface Viewer to explore a complex window with many layers of controls, it is sometimes difficult to locate the UI explorer tree node corresponding to a given physical control. The point-to-identify feature, invoked via the Identify button on the Viewer's toolbar, simplifies this process.

shortdesc.p: The Highlight feature of the Interface Viewer might be considered the flip side of the point-to-identify coin. Whereas point-to-identify allows you to start with a known control or window on an application and find its node in the UI explorer panel, Highlight allows you to start from a node in the tree and locate the physical object it represents.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Highlight feature of the Interface Viewer might be considered the flip side of the point-to-identify coin. Whereas point-to-identify allows you to start with a known control or window on an application and find its node in the UI explorer panel, Highlight allows you to start from a node in the tree and locate the physical object it represents.

shortdesc.p: The Interface Viewer retains captured UI controls and their properties even after they are no longer available from the AUT.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Interface Viewer retains captured UI controls and their properties even after they are no longer available from the AUT.

shortdesc.p: Save, Refresh, Open vs. Active, HTML tags filter, Copy Value, Class Mapping, Show Invisible Windows, Show Invisible Controls, Show All Processes functionalities are discussed in this section.

shortdesc.p: Web pages are composed of HTML elements rather than controls, with each element type specified by a tag. Web applications can often have pages with a large number of tags that you really have no need to interface with for proper testing. The Interface Viewer helps you by allowing you to limit the elements displayed in the UI explorer to only certain types, excluding all others.

Web applications can often have pages with a large number of tags that you really have no need to interface with for proper testing. The Interface Viewer helps you by allowing you to limit the elements displayed in the UI explorer to only certain types, excluding all others.

shortdesc.p: The purpose of UI Automation technology is to expose rich information about the UI elements used in Windows applications.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The purpose of UI Automation technology is to expose rich information about the UI elements used in Windows applications.

shortdesc.p: To hasten the process of capturing all available controls belonging to a specific TA class, you can use the Capture all controls function in the Interface Viewer.

shortdesc.p: The Text Recognition feature in the Interface Viewer helps you determine which drawing Windows APIs should be employed. The employed APIs will help the Graphics Device Interface (GDI) built-in actions detect text produced by the AUT.

topic.title: Addressing windows, controls of MDI apps

shortdesc.p: This topic explains how TestArchitect significantly enhances the UI matching process performance for Multiple Document Interface (MDI) applications during test automation

topicmeta.navtitle: Addressing windows, controls of MDI apps
topicmeta.linktext: Addressing windows, controls of Multiple Document Interface applications
topicmeta.shortdesc: This topic explains how TestArchitect significantly enhances the UI matching process performance for Multiple Document Interface (MDI) applications during test automation

shortdesc.p: To address controls of MDI applications, TestArchitect maps the controls as MDI-child windows.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To address controls of MDI applications, TestArchitect maps the controls as MDI-child windows.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect employs a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to match a desired MDI-child window and its controls.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect employs a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to match a desired MDI-child window and its controls.

shortdesc.p: Interface entities can be exported to archive files (.ZIP format), which can be used as a backup or for re-importing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Interface entities can be exported to archive files ( .ZIP format), which can be used as a backup or for re-importing.

shortdesc.p: You can import an interface entity into your project from one that has been saved to a .ZIP archive file.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can import an interface entity into your project from one that has been saved to a .ZIP archive file.

shortdesc.p: To address the complexity introduced by the variety of native control classes, TestArchitect introduces the concept of TA classes. TA classes represent a “common core” of control classes that TestArchitect's built-in actions and methods are designed to interface with. Class mapping is the process of relating the various control classes of each software platform to their corresponding TA classes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To address the complexity introduced by the variety of native control classes, TestArchitect introduces the concept of TA classes. TA classes represent a common core of control classes that TestArchitect's built-in actions and methods are designed to interface with. Class mapping is the process of relating the various control classes of each software platform to their corresponding TA classes.

shortdesc.p: For every new interface created in TestArchitect, a default $ Class Maps entity is assigned. This entity is user-editable and allows for user-defined mappings to be created between native control classes and TA classes.

topicmeta.shortdesc: For every new interface created in TestArchitect, a default $ Class Maps entity is assigned. This entity is user-editable and allows for user-defined mappings to be created between native control classes and TA classes.

shortdesc.p: In some cases, the Interface Viewer encounters a control whose class it does not know about. (These are indicated by red question marks in their nodes in the Viewer's UI explorer tree.) When that happens, if you need to interface with the control, or with other controls of that class, you must map the unknown native class to a suitable TA class.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In some cases, the Interface Viewer encounters a control whose class it does not know about. (These are indicated by red question marks in their nodes in the Viewer's UI explorer tree.) When that happens, if you need to interface with the control, or with other controls of that class, you must map the unknown native class to a suitable TA class.

shortdesc.p: You have options to have TestArchitect display more classes rather than display only the classes containing UI Automation peers.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect 8 Update 2 enhances Android class mapping to introduce new supported and mapped Android controls. Prior versions of TestArchitect used the generic class for unrecognized Android controls.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect 8 Update 2 enhances Android class mapping to introduce new supported and mapped Android controls. Prior versions of TestArchitect used the generic class for unrecognized Android controls.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect 8.3 enhances Windows Forms (WinForms) class mapping to allow WinForms controls to be mapped to TestArchitect's set of TA classes. Note that these TA classes support the full range of TestArchitect built-in actions, affording your tests more power and flexibility.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect 8.3 enhances Windows Forms (WinForms) class mapping to allow WinForms controls to be mapped to TestArchitect's set of TA classes. Note that these TA classes support the full range of TestArchitect built-in actions, affording your tests more power and flexibility.

shortdesc.p: For each known class of control, TestArchitect uses internal mapping files to map its native properties to a set of TA properties.

topicmeta.shortdesc: For each known class of control, TestArchitect uses internal mapping files to map its native properties to a set of TA properties.

shortdesc.p: A primary TA property is one that obtains its value directly from a given native property.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A primary TA property is one that obtains its value directly from a given native property.

shortdesc.p: The positional properties of a control specify its location and dimensions.

topicmeta.navtitle: Positional properties ( left, top, width, height)
topicmeta.shortdesc: The positional properties of a control specify its location and dimensions.

shortdesc.p: While most TA properties get their values directly from single native properties of their associated controls, there are some TA properties whose values are calculated, often from two or more native properties, or from other controls. We'll examine a few examples.

topicmeta.shortdesc: While most TA properties get their values directly from single native properties of their associated controls, there are some TA properties whose values are calculated, often from two or more native properties, or from other controls. We'll examine a few examples.

topic.title: Using global pos to identify UI elements

shortdesc.p: global pos is a TA property that is generated by TestArchitect for each available control of a given window, and is essentially independent of any of that control's native properties. Each such control is assigned a global pos value that is unique within that window.

topicmeta.navtitle: Using global pos to identify UI elements
topicmeta.linktext: Using global pos to identify UI elements
topicmeta.shortdesc: global pos is a TA property that is generated by TestArchitect for each available control of a given window, and is essentially independent of any of that control's native properties. Each such control is assigned a global pos value that is unique within that window.

shortdesc.p: anchor pos is a secondary property that, like global pos, is used to identify a control independent of any inherent property-value pairs. The use of anchor pos is an often more reliable means of identifying a control than global pos, and is recommended over global pos.

topicmeta.shortdesc: anchor pos is a secondary property that, like global pos, is used to identify a control independent of any inherent property-value pairs. The use of anchor pos is an often more reliable means of identifying a control than global pos, and is recommended over global pos.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Using anchor and anchor pos properties within multilevel dynamic identifiers is often essential to ensure that you are targeting the right controls.

shortdesc.p: column headers is a secondary TA property that applies to certain grid-style controls with column labels. It simply maintains the text content of all the headers in one long string.

topicmeta.shortdesc: column headers is a secondary TA property that applies to certain grid-style controls with column labels. It simply maintains the text content of all the headers in one long string.

shortdesc.p: index path is a secondary TA property that uses one or two index values to specify the position of a cell in either a table view or collection view structure in iOS.

topicmeta.shortdesc: index path is a secondary TA property that uses one or two index values to specify the position of a cell in either a table view or collection view structure in iOS.

shortdesc.p: label is a TA property that TestArchitect assigns to a number of different types of controls. A control's label value is usually unique within a window, hence it often serves as a useful identifier, one that you can use to reliably map the control to a TA name.

topicmeta.shortdesc: label is a TA property that TestArchitect assigns to a number of different types of controls. A control's label value is usually unique within a window, hence it often serves as a useful identifier, one that you can use to reliably map the control to a TA name.

shortdesc.p: Associating controls with labels donated from other controls is a multi-step process. The procedure implemented by TestArchitect requires precise definitions of what constitutes alignment between controls, proximity of controls, and determining the distance between them. Those technical details are explained here.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Associating controls with labels donated from other controls is a multi-step process. The procedure implemented by TestArchitect requires precise definitions of what constitutes alignment between controls, proximity of controls, and determining the distance between them. Those technical details are explained here.

shortdesc.p: node path is a secondary TA property that specifies the position of a cell in a treeview control in the WPF and UIA platforms.

topicmeta.shortdesc: node path is a secondary TA property that specifies the position of a cell in a treeview control in the WPF and UIA platforms.

shortdesc.p: text, in some cases, is a secondary property, with its value derived from other controls.

topicmeta.shortdesc: text, in some cases, is a secondary property, with its value derived from other controls.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect uses a special TA property, called XPath and derived from the XPath language, to uniquely locate UI controls within tested web applications.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect uses a special TA property, called XPath and derived from the XPath language, to uniquely locate UI controls within tested web applications.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect scans application windows for their controls during both the identification and playback phases of testing, to establish the controls' TA classes, TA properties and TA property values. This is called the intake process.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect scans application windows for their controls during both the identification and playback phases of testing, to establish the controls' TA classes, TA properties and TA property values. This is called the intake process.

shortdesc.p: Dynamic identifiers allow the identification of controls and windows to be made under program control, rather than with interface definitions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Dynamic identifiers allow the identification of controls and windows to be made under program control, rather than with interface definitions.

shortdesc.p: Container classes are classes of UI controls that can contain other controls. Because the number of child controls that a container holds is potentially unlimited, such container classes present possible performance hits during test runs. To avoid such issues, TestArchitect offers the option of bypassing the recognition of container child controls.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Container classes are classes of UI controls that can contain other controls. Because the number of child controls that a container holds is potentially unlimited, such container classes present possible performance hits during test runs. To avoid such issues, TestArchitect offers the option of bypassing the recognition of container child controls.

shortdesc.p: To capture child UI elements of a container class, that container class must first be unlocked.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To capture child UI elements of a container class, that container class must first be unlocked.

shortdesc.p: How to interact dynamically with the child UI elements of a container class.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect seamlessly integrates with several powerful third-party tools, to assist in application development, continuous integration, test management, and bug tracking. topic.title: Mapping a TestArchitect project to a Quality Center project

shortdesc.p: Integration between projects in TestArchitect and Quality Center requires that a mapping first be established between the two projects. Mapping a TestArchitect project to a project in Quality Center allows tests be transferred bidirectionally, test results to be posted from TestArchitect to Quality Center, and tests to be run from Quality Center.

topic.title: Creating matching custom fields in TestArchitect and Quality Center

shortdesc.p: User-defined fields in TestArchitect are automatically mapped to their counterparts in Quality Center, when such counterparts exist.

topicmeta.navtitle: Creating matching custom fields in TestArchitect and Quality Center
topicmeta.shortdesc: User-defined fields in TestArchitect are automatically mapped to their counterparts in Quality Center, when such counterparts exist.

shortdesc.p: Mapping is driven by field names. Fields in Quality Center and TestArchitect are mapped to each other automatically when a), their names are identical, b), their data types are compatible, and c), the TestArchitect Apply To entity is matched properly with the Quality Center Project entity. When uploading from TestArchitect to Quality Center, values fromTestArchitect user-defined fields are loaded into their corresponding fields in Quality Center. Likewise, values from Quality Center custom fields are loaded into the corresponding TestArchitect user-defined fields when importing tests from Quality Center to TestArchitect.

topicmeta.linktext: Rules for mapping custom fields between TestArchitect and Quality Center
topicmeta.shortdesc: Mapping is driven by field names. Fields in Quality Center and TestArchitect are mapped to each other automatically when a), their names are identical, b), their data types are compatible, and c), the TestArchitect Apply To entity is matched properly with the Quality Center Project entity. When uploading from TestArchitect to Quality Center, values from TestArchitect user-defined fields are loaded into their corresponding fields in Quality Center. Likewise, values from Quality Center custom fields are loaded into the corresponding TestArchitect user-defined fields when importing tests from Quality Center to TestArchitect.

shortdesc.p: By default, the test objectives that may be assigned to TestArchitect test modules and test cases are not carried over to Quality Center tests. You can remedy that, however, by creating a special test objective custom field.

topicmeta.linktext: Creating a custom test objective field in Quality Center
topicmeta.shortdesc: By default, the test objectives that may be assigned to TestArchitect test modules and test cases are not carried over to Quality Center tests. You can remedy that, however, by creating a special test objective custom field.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect™ can be integrated into Team Foundation Server (TFS)® allowing you to include your TestArchitect tests in your application’s lifecycle managed by the Visual Studio and Visual Studio Team Foundation tools. You can associate your TestArchitect test cases with TFS test cases in your test plan and run the plan as an automated test in MTM.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect can be integrated into Team Foundation Server (TFS) allowing you to include your TestArchitect tests in your application’s lifecycle managed by the Visual Studio and Visual Studio Team Foundation tools. You can associate your TestArchitect test cases with TFS test cases in your test plan and run the plan as an automated test in MTM.

shortdesc.p: TFS together with MTM or the Test hub allows you to leverage the test development and test run capabilities of TestArchitect with a host of software tools offered by Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) ecosystem. To fully exploit these offerings, it is helpful to have an understanding of the Microsoft ALM and its components.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TFS together with MTM or the Test hub allows you to leverage the test development and test run capabilities of TestArchitect with a host of software tools offered by Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) ecosystem. To fully exploit these offerings, it is helpful to have an understanding of the Microsoft ALM and its components.

shortdesc.p: Team Foundation Server (TFS) is a Microsoft product which provides source code management, reporting, requirements management, project management, automated builds, lab management, testing and release management capabilities.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Team Foundation Server (TFS) is a Microsoft product which provides source code management, reporting, requirements management, project management, automated builds, lab management, testing and release management capabilities.

shortdesc.p: Continuous Integration (CI) is a development practice that requires developers to integrate code into a shared repository several times a day. Each check-in is then verified by an automated build, allowing teams to detect problems early.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Continuous Integration (CI) is a development practice that requires developers to integrate code into a shared repository several times a day. Each check-in is then verified by an automated build, allowing teams to detect problems early.

shortdesc.p: Contains information of supported Microsoft technologies.

topic.title: Installing and configuring Microsoft components for on-premises TFS

shortdesc.p: This section and its subtopics list out a number of components of Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) environment that need to be installed and configured for on-premises TFS.

topicmeta.navtitle: Installing and configuring Microsoft components for on-premises TFS

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section and its subtopics list out a number of components of Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) environment that need to be installed and configured for on-premises TFS.

shortdesc.p: A fully functional TA-TFS integrated system requires that a number of components of Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) environment be installed and configured.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A fully functional TA-TFS integrated system requires that a number of components of Microsoft's Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) environment be installed and configured.

shortdesc.p: To use Team Foundation Build (TFBuild) with an on-premise TFS, you must deploy at least one build server. Each build server serves a single team project collection. Although you configure, modify, and manage a build server on the computer where Team Foundation Build Service is running, the configuration data is stored in the team project collection.

topicmeta.linktext: Deploying and configuring a build server for TFS-MTM integration
topicmeta.shortdesc: To use Team Foundation Build (TFBuild) with an on-premise TFS, you must deploy at least one build server. Each build server serves a single team project collection. Although you configure, modify, and manage a build server on the computer where Team Foundation Build Service is running, the configuration data is stored in the team project collection.

shortdesc.p: To use Team Foundation Build (TFBuild), you must have at least one build controller, which pools and manages the services of one or more build agents. It distributes processor-intensive work: for example, compiling code or running tests, etc., to the build agents. Each build controller is dedicated to a single team project collection.

topicmeta.linktext: Deploying and configuring a build controller for TFS-MTM integration
topicmeta.shortdesc: To use Team Foundation Build (TFBuild), you must have at least one build controller, which pools and manages the services of one or more build agents. It distributes processor-intensive work: for example, compiling code or running tests, etc., to the build agents. Each build controller is dedicated to a single team project collection.

shortdesc.p: With Team Foundation Build (TFBuild), you can create and manage build processes that automatically compile and test your applications, and perform other important functions. You can use your build system to support a strategy of continuous integration or put even more rigorous quality checks in place that prevent bad quality code from breaking the build.

topicmeta.linktext: Deploying and configuring a build agent for TFS-MTM integration
topicmeta.shortdesc: With Team Foundation Build (TFBuild), you can create and manage build processes that automatically compile and test your applications, and perform other important functions. You can use your build system to support a strategy of continuous integration or put even more rigorous quality checks in place that prevent bad quality code from breaking the build.

shortdesc.p: To use TFBuild, you must have at least one build agent. A build agent does the processor-intensive work of your build, which includes getting files from version control, provisioning the workspace, compiling the code, running tests, and merging files back into version control. Each build agent is dedicated to a single build controller.

topicmeta.shortdesc: To use TFBuild, you must have at least one build agent. A build agent does the processor-intensive work of your build, which includes getting files from version control, provisioning the workspace, compiling the code, running tests, and merging files back into version control. Each build agent is dedicated to a single build controller.

When you configure a test controller for a lab environment, you have to register it with your team project collection.

topic.title: Setting up the MTM test agent

shortdesc.p: A test agent must be installed on each machine on which you intend to deploy your automated test, and on each machine to be used to collect test data. This section describes how to install a test agent and register it with a test controller.

topic.title: Automating a test case in MTM

shortdesc.p: To successfully automate a test case in Microsoft Test Manager (MTM), numerous steps must be taken. These include creating TFS test cases, creating UI tests, linking test cases to test methods, creating a lab environment and settings to run your tests, and more. Additionally, in this section, a simple coded UI test project is created to let you verify that the entire AUT, including its user interface, is functioning correctly.

shortdesc.p: To enable integration between TestArchitect and a continuous integration (CI) tool, an xUnit-format XML file must be imported into the tool. This XML file is created by extracting the test result of one or more test modules executed by TestArchitect.

shortdesc.p: In order to execute TestArchitect test cases or test modules from Zephyr, a Zephyr Bot (ZBot) agent is required to form the link between the Zephyr server and the TestArchitect Client on your machine. Additionally, a custom TestArchitect ZIP project must be deployed on the TestArchitect Client machine.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In order to execute TestArchitect test cases or test modules from Zephyr, a Zephyr Bot (ZBot) agent is required to form the link between the Zephyr server and the TestArchitect Client on your machine. Additionally, a custom TestArchitect ZIP project must be deployed on the TestArchitect Client machine.

shortdesc.p: If it is no longer required, you may terminate the connection between the Zephyr server and your TestArchitect repository.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect's support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect's support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on.

shortdesc.p: Connecting a TestArchitect repository to an LDAP-based directory service is your first step in allowing users of the repository to take advantage of LDAP's single sign-on functionality.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Connecting a TestArchitect repository to an LDAP-based directory service is your first step in allowing users of the repository to take advantage of LDAP's single sign-on functionality.

shortdesc.p: This is where you “flip the switch”, telling TestArchitect that user authentications for a given repository are to be handled not by TestArchitect, but by LDAP.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This is where you flip the switch, telling TestArchitect that user authentications for a given repository are to be handled not by TestArchitect, but by LDAP.

topic.title: Matching LDAP user names with repository user names

shortdesc.p: Regardless of whether user authentications for a repository are performed by TestArchitect or LDAP, it is the TestArchitect user name that determines which permissions are granted to each user. Hence, to use LDAP, it is necessary to associate the LDAP user name of each user of the repository with his/her TestArchitect user name.

topicmeta.navtitle: Matching LDAP user names with repository user names
topicmeta.linktext: Matching LDAP user names with repository user names
topicmeta.shortdesc: Regardless of whether user authentications for a repository are performed by TestArchitect or LDAP, it is the TestArchitect user name that determines which permissions are granted to each user. Hence, to use LDAP, it is necessary to associate the LDAP user name of each user of the repository with his/her TestArchitect user name.

shortdesc.p: Variations allow you to adapt your test project to any number of changes to, or versions of, an AUT or platform, while preserving the project's existing functionality.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Variations allow you to adapt your test project to any number of changes to, or versions of, an AUT or platform, while preserving the project's existing functionality.

p.span: Ideally, a test should not be sensitive to changes to the AUT, except when such changes are the subject of the test. Variations help isolate the base test from AUT variability, and lend a great measure of flexibility to your test project.

shortdesc.ph: Ideally, a test should not be sensitive to changes to the AUT, except when such changes are the subject of the test. Variations help isolate the base test from AUT variability, and lend a great measure of flexibility to your test project.

shortdesc.p: Every project item with variations must also have a default, or base, variation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Every project item with variations must also have a default, or base, variation.

shortdesc.p: Keyword variations define certain categories of distinctions between different system/platform mixes, where the differences generally are not due to any progressive development or refinement of any aspect of the mix.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Keyword variations define certain categories of distinctions between different system/platform mixes, where the differences generally are not due to any progressive development or refinement of any aspect of the mix.

shortdesc.p: Linked variations are the preferred method for addressing what might be termed progressive variability.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Linked variations are the preferred method for addressing what might be termed progressive variability.

shortdesc.p: The linked variations solution is based upon a user-generated model of the various systems which affect the behavior of the application under test.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The linked variations solution is based upon a user-generated model of the various systems which affect the behavior of the application under test.

shortdesc.p: Create a new system tree to represent a given dimension of variability of an application under test, or of its environment.

topicmeta.linktext: Creating a new system (application under test)
topicmeta.shortdesc: Create a new system tree to represent a given dimension of variability of an application under test, or of its environment.

shortdesc.p: Create version nodes to represent specific variations of a given system.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Create version nodes to represent specific variations of a given system.

shortdesc.p: A branch node is typically used to represent a minor update to a version of a system, the system usually being the AUT.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A branch node is typically used to represent a minor update to a version of a system, the system usually being the AUT.

topic.title: Maintaining and modifying a system tree

shortdesc.p: As is evident from the context menu for any node in the Systems and Platforms tree, nodes may be renamed, and can be added or deleted from the tree. What is not directly evident is that, to a limited degree, a tree's structure may also be modified by rearranging its nodes and subtrees.

shortdesc.p: Rules for creating variations.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Rules for creating variations.

shortdesc.p: Each variation of a given project item definition must be linked to the same system, or to no system at all.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Each variation of a given project item definition must be linked to the same system, or to no system at all.

shortdesc.p: A variation may be linked to only one system. However, that variation may be linked to multiple version nodes belonging to a single system.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A variation may be linked to only one system. However, that variation may be linked to multiple version nodes belonging to a single system.

topic.title: Assigning a keyword signature to a variation

shortdesc.p: A given variation is identified by its variation signature: the combination of the system versions it is linked to (system signature) and the keywords assigned to it (keyword signature). This topic discusses the keyword signature.

topicmeta.navtitle: Assigning a keyword signature to a variation
topicmeta.linktext: Assigning a keyword signature to a variation
topicmeta.shortdesc: A given variation is identified by its variation signature: the combination of the system versions it is linked to ( system signature) and the keywords assigned to it ( keyword signature). This topic discusses the keyword signature.

shortdesc.p: For each effective variation of a given project item, the combination of version signature and keyword signature must be unique. TestArchitect enforces that uniqueness when you create new variations.

topicmeta.shortdesc: For each effective variation of a given project item, the combination of version signature and keyword signature must be unique. TestArchitect enforces that uniqueness when you create new variations.

shortdesc.p: As discussed, it is at the start of execution that you inform TestArchitect of the specific versions of systems (we'll call these system/versions) that apply to your test run, as well as any applicable keywords.

topicmeta.shortdesc: As discussed, it is at the start of execution that you inform TestArchitect of the specific versions of systems (we'll call these system/versions) that apply to your test run, as well as any applicable keywords.

shortdesc.p: At runtime setup, you have the option of supplying a variation specification to determine which variations of the required project items will be invoked for the test run. It is possible that certain invoked project items will not have variations that are exact matches with your runtime variation spec. In each such instance, TestArchitect applies a set of rules to determine the variation that is to be activated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: At runtime setup, you have the option of supplying a variation specification to determine which variations of the required project items will be invoked for the test run. It is possible that certain invoked project items will not have variations that are exact matches with your runtime variation spec. In each such instance, TestArchitect applies a set of rules to determine the variation that is to be activated.

shortdesc.p: At execution setup, you have the option of specifying a version variation for each defined system in your repository's Systems & Platforms tree.

topicmeta.shortdesc:
At execution setup, you have the option of specifying a version variation for each defined system in your repository's
Systems & Platforms tree.

topic.title: Rules for selecting variations for execution

shortdesc.p: Obviously, if execution of a test run is specified with the Keyword Spanish and the AUT Version Car Rental: 1.2, and the test module calls, say, the user-defined login action, then the {Car Rental: 1.2} {Spanish} variation of login is invoked – if that variation exists!

topicmeta.navtitle: Rules for selecting variations for execution
topicmeta.linktext: Rules for selecting variations for execution
topicmeta.shortdesc: Obviously, if execution of a test run is specified with the Keyword Spanish and the AUT Version Car Rental: 1.2, and the test module calls, say, the user-defined login action, then the {Car Rental: 1.2} {Spanish} variation of login is invoked – if that variation exists!

shortdesc.p: If, at the start of execution, both fields (Keyword and AUT Version) of the Variation Specification section are left blank, then the default variation of an invoked test module, action, interface, or data set constitutes an exact match, and is invoked.

topicmeta.shortdesc: If, at the start of execution, both fields ( Keyword and AUT Version) of the Variation Specification section are left blank, then the default variation of an invoked test module, action, interface, or data set constitutes an exact match, and is invoked.

shortdesc.p: When a test is launched with keywords specified, applies a set of rules to determine the appropriate variations to use.

topicmeta.shortdesc: When a test is launched with keywords specified, applies a set of rules to determine the appropriate variations to use.

shortdesc.p: In this scenario, the runtime variation specification contains no keywords, but one or more system/version nodes are provided (that is, there is a version run set).

topicmeta.shortdesc: In this scenario, the runtime variation specification contains no keywords, but one or more system/version nodes are provided (that is, there is a version run set).

topic.title: Execution with both keywords and version nodes

shortdesc.p: When the Execute Test dialog box's runtime variation specification includes both keywords and version nodes, the decision-making performed is largely a combination of those described in the previous two cases.

topicmeta.navtitle: Execution with both keywords and version nodes
topicmeta.linktext: Execution with both keywords and version nodes
topicmeta.shortdesc: When the Execute Test dialog box's runtime variation specification includes both keywords and version nodes, the decision-making performed is largely a combination of those described in the previous two cases.

shortdesc.p: How to execute a test on single device or multiple devices, remotely or locally.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to execute a test on single device or multiple devices, remotely or locally.

shortdesc.p: The are numerous methods of executing automated tests.

topic.title: Executing tests from the command line interface

shortdesc.p: With TestArchitect's command line tool, tests can be launched from a command shell. When incorporated into batch files, the tool greatly extends the flexibility of test execution, especially from the standpoint of scheduling.

topicmeta.navtitle: Executing tests from the command line interface
topicmeta.linktext: Executing tests from the command line interface
topicmeta.shortdesc: With TestArchitect's command line tool, tests can be launched from a command shell. When incorporated into batch files, the tool greatly extends the flexibility of test execution, especially from the standpoint of scheduling.

topic.title: Offline execution - The test execution batch file

shortdesc.p: From a TestArchitect client session, you can generate a batch file that invokes the command line tool to perform your tests.

topicmeta.navtitle: Offline execution - The test execution batch file
topicmeta.linktext: Offline execution - The test execution batch file
topicmeta.shortdesc: From a TestArchitect client session, you can generate a batch file that invokes the command line tool to perform your tests.

shortdesc.p: How to have TestArchitect generate a test execution batch file for you, with all the arguments set in accordance with your preferences.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to have TestArchitect generate a test execution batch file for you, with all the arguments set in accordance with your preferences.

shortdesc.p: The TestArchitect system allows you to launch a test on remote hosts and/or devices attached to the hosts, provided that each host has a TestArchitect Controller installed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The TestArchitect system allows you to launch a test on remote hosts and/or devices attached to the hosts, provided that each host has a TestArchitect Controller installed.

shortdesc.p: Asynchronous testing allows you to run a test on multiple remote controllers.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Asynchronous testing allows you to run a test on multiple remote controllers.

shortdesc.p: In synchronous remote execution, tests are run that typically involve multiple machines interacting with each other, or accessing the same resource.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In synchronous remote execution, tests are run that typically involve multiple machines interacting with each other, or accessing the same resource.

shortdesc.p: Under serial synchronous remote execution, control is initiated with the lead controller.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Under serial synchronous remote execution, control is initiated with the lead controller.

shortdesc.p: In some cases it is necessary to test applications, or multiple instances of an application, for their interactions with each other, or for their joint effect on some shared resource such as a database.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In some cases it is necessary to test applications, or multiple instances of an application, for their interactions with each other, or for their joint effect on some shared resource such as a database.

shortdesc.p: An automated test can be run on multiple devices attached to a local host, and/or on multiple controllers, and/or on multiple devices attached to the controllers.

topicmeta.shortdesc: An automated test can be run on multiple devices attached to a local host, and/or on multiple controllers, and/or on multiple devices attached to the controllers.

shortdesc.p: Typical issues that you may encounter when executing tests on multiple devices, and possible solutions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Typical issues that you may encounter when executing tests on multiple devices, and possible solutions.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect provides you the capability to execute tests with multiple remote desktop sessions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect provides you the capability to execute tests with multiple remote desktop sessions.
