topicmeta.shortdesc: How to run multiple test harnesses simultaneously with a single controller.

topic.title: Running multiple harnesses from TestArchitect Client

shortdesc.p: Running multiple harnesses is to execute different test modules/suites with a single TA Controller simultaneously.

topicmeta.navtitle: Running multiple harnesses from TestArchitect Client
topicmeta.linktext: Running multiple harnesses from TestArchitect Client
topicmeta.shortdesc: Running multiple harnesses is to execute different test modules/suites with a single TA Controller simultaneously.

topic.title: Creating a batch file to run multiple harnesses

shortdesc.p: You can create a batch file that calls batch files to execute TestArchitect tests simultaneously.

topicmeta.navtitle: Creating a batch file to run multiple harnesses
topicmeta.linktext: Creating a batch file to run multiple harnesses
topicmeta.shortdesc: You can create a batch file that calls batch files to execute TestArchitect tests simultaneously.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect allows you to determine the maximum allowable number of harnesses (harness pool size) running on a TestArchitect controller at a time.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect allows you to determine the maximum allowable number of harnesses (harness pool size) running on a TestArchitect controller at a time.

shortdesc.p: The playback toolbar appears at the bottom right corner of the screen during test execution. It displays the list of running harnesses and their running statuses, and allows you to pause, resume, or terminate the harnesses.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The playback toolbar appears at the bottom right corner of the screen during test execution. It displays the list of running harnesses and their running statuses, and allows you to pause, resume, or terminate the harnesses.

shortdesc.p: Time-traveling execution provides the support for "retroactive" execution; that is, the ability to execute a particular set of revisions of project items in a given project.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Time-traveling execution provides the support for "retroactive" execution; that is, the ability to execute a particular set of revisions of project items in a given project.

shortdesc.p: How to perform retroactive execution of historical revisions of project items.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to perform retroactive execution of historical revisions of project items.

shortdesc.p: You have the option of supplying a specific timestamp to determine which revision of the given test module will be executed backward for the test run. It is possible that certain invoked test module and other related project items will not have the revision that is exact matches with your supplied timestamp. In this circumstance, TestArchitect applies a set of rules to determine the revision that is to be activated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You have the option of supplying a specific timestamp to determine which revision of the given test module will be executed backward for the test run. It is possible that certain invoked test module and other related project items will not have the revision that is exact matches with your supplied timestamp. In this circumstance, TestArchitect applies a set of rules to determine the revision that is to be activated.

shortdesc.p: Reviewing test results can assist you in verifying which revision of each related project items is selected to run.

topicmeta.linktext: Reviewing test results with time traveling
topicmeta.shortdesc: Reviewing test results can assist you in verifying which revision of each related project items is selected to run.

shortdesc.p: Startup settings are settings which you can configure before launching a test run. These settings are of two types: built-in, and user-defined.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Startup settings are settings which you can configure before launching a test run. These settings are of two types: built-in, and user-defined.

shortdesc.p: User-defined settings are a useful way of passing information to your test modules prior to startup to get them to behave in a certain way. You can create these settings within TestArchitect Client for either a client-directed test run or to generate a test run batch file.

topicmeta.shortdesc: User-defined settings are a useful way of passing information to your test modules prior to startup to get them to behave in a certain way. You can create these settings within TestArchitect Client for either a client-directed test run or to generate a test run batch file.

topic.title: Creating a startup setting for a built-in setting

shortdesc.p: In addition to being modifiable from within your test procedures, built-in settings can have their values set by you just prior to the launch of your test run.

topicmeta.navtitle: Creating a startup setting for a built-in setting
topicmeta.linktext: Creating a startup setting for a built-in setting
topicmeta.shortdesc: In addition to being modifiable from within your test procedures, built-in settings can have their values set by you just prior to the launch of your test run.

shortdesc.p: You can edit the startup attributes of existing user-defined and built-in settings.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can edit the startup attributes of existing user-defined and built-in settings.

shortdesc.p: You can delete startup settings of both user-defined and built-in settings.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can delete startup settings of both user-defined and built-in settings.

shortdesc.p: Once a harness run completes or is prematurely terminated, its execution information is logged to files.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Once a harness run completes or is prematurely terminated, its execution information is logged to files.

shortdesc.p: Log files may take up a lot of hard disk space over time. Therefore, TestArchitect offers you a mechanism to automatically delete old log files.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Log files may take up a lot of hard disk space over time. Therefore, TestArchitect offers you a mechanism to automatically delete old log files.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect offers two tools to aid you in the quick identification of errors, warnings, and failures: the debugger, and screenshot recording.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect offers two tools to aid you in the quick identification of errors, warnings, and failures: the debugger, and screenshot recording.

shortdesc.p: The TestArchitect debugger allows you to run an application under test interactively while observing the action lines and results at each stage of execution, as well as the state of the AUT. Variables, arguments, and settings at each stage may also be observed, and modified.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The TestArchitect debugger allows you to run an application under test interactively while observing the action lines and results at each stage of execution, as well as the state of the AUT. Variables, arguments, and settings at each stage may also be observed, and modified.

shortdesc.p: With execution halted, the debugger toolbar offers various functional buttons to help you debug the action lines.

topicmeta.shortdesc: With execution halted, the debugger toolbar offers various functional buttons to help you debug the action lines.

shortdesc.p: A breakpoint is a location in your action lines that has been designated as a point at which execution is to be paused. With execution thus halted, you can view information about the running application's state at the given point.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A breakpoint is a location in your action lines that has been designated as a point at which execution is to be paused. With execution thus halted, you can view information about the running application's state at the given point.

shortdesc.p: After defining breakpoints, you can run your test procedure through the debugger.

topicmeta.shortdesc: After defining breakpoints, you can run your test procedure through the debugger.

shortdesc.p: If you no longer need a breakpoint, delete it.

topicmeta.shortdesc: If you no longer need a breakpoint, delete it.

shortdesc.p: Sometimes you may want to disable a breakpoint without doing away with it entirely. Execution is not paused when it meets a disabled breakpoint. The breakpoint remains marked in the margin for your reference, and can be re-enabled when again needed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Sometimes you may want to disable a breakpoint without doing away with it entirely. Execution is not paused when it meets a disabled breakpoint. The breakpoint remains marked in the margin for your reference, and can be re-enabled when again needed.

shortdesc.p: Reactivating a disabled breakpoint.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reactivating a disabled breakpoint.

topicmeta.shortdesc: How to debug a harness in a remote desktop session.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect allows snapshots to be automatically taken of the AUT's display at various critical points during test execution. By letting you observe the display state of the AUT at each stage of the test, you can have a better grasp of where and how a test, or application, is going wrong.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect allows snapshots to be automatically taken of the AUT's display at various critical points during test execution. By letting you observe the display state of the AUT at each stage of the test, you can have a better grasp of where and how a test, or application, is going wrong.

shortdesc.p: With screenshot recording active,TestArchitect captures screenshots during test execution for each UI-interactive action. Depending on your settings, it retains some of these screenshots and logs them to the generated test result.

topicmeta.shortdesc: With screenshot recording active, TestArchitect captures screenshots during test execution for each UI-interactive action. Depending on your settings, it retains some of these screenshots and logs them to the generated test result.

shortdesc.p: Test automation is managed by the TestArchitect Controller application, which interacts with and obtains vital test run information from the interpreter. A machine on which TestArchitect Controller is running is referred to as a controller.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Test automation is managed by the TestArchitect Controller application, which interacts with and obtains vital test run information from the interpreter. A machine on which TestArchitect Controller is running is referred to as a controller.

shortdesc.p: You can change controller settings via the TestArchitect Controller icon on the system tray.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can change controller settings via the TestArchitect Controller icon on the system tray.

topic.title: Starting TestArchitect Controller from a command line interface

shortdesc.p: you are able to start TestArchitect Controller with a new port from a command line interface using either TAController or TACTRL command.

topicmeta.linktext: Starting TestArchitect Controller from a command line interface
topicmeta.shortdesc: you are able to start TestArchitect Controller with a new port from a command line interface using either TAController or TACTRL command.

topic.title: Changing a TestArchitect Controller port number

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect Controllers use a default port number of 53600. You can reassign a controller to any valid port number of your choice, so long as the port is not already in use.

topicmeta.navtitle: Changing a TestArchitect Controller port number
topicmeta.linktext: Changing a TestArchitect Controller port number
topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect Controllers use a default port number of 53600. You can reassign a controller to any valid port number of your choice, so long as the port is not already in use.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect supports users in changing the TA command line port number to resolve port conflicts.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect supports users in changing the TA command line port number to resolve port conflicts.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect automatically generates a report containing the results of an automated test after the test concludes. The test results are immediately displayed in the main window of TestArchitect Client.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect automatically generates a report containing the results of an automated test after the test concludes. The test results are immediately displayed in the main window of TestArchitect Client.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This topic contains information about various tabs and panels, and on viewing test results.

shortdesc.p: The test result Summary tab reports basic test run information which summarizes various aspects of the test. A summary report represents the results of a single run of one test module.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The test result Summary tab reports basic test run information which summarizes various aspects of the test. A summary report represents the results of a single run of one test module.

shortdesc.p: The Result Details tab displays a detailed (line-by-line) log of the test execution, which can be essential for test run analysis and debugging.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Result Details tab displays a detailed (line-by-line) log of the test execution, which can be essential for test run analysis and debugging.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reviewing test results can assist you in determining if and when JIRA bug issues on a JIRA server should be closed.

shortdesc.p: This section displays all failure, error, or warning encountered during the test run.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section displays all failure, error, or warning encountered during the test run.

shortdesc.p: The test result Information tab displays general information about the test, including the date, time and duration of the test run, the type of machine or device running the test, the AUT version, etc. The numbers of test cases flagged as Passed, Failed, Warning, Error, and Ignored Fails are also displayed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The test result Information tab displays general information about the test, including the date, time and duration of the test run, the type of machine or device running the test, the AUT version, etc. The numbers of test cases flagged as Passed, Failed, Warning, Error, and Ignored Fails are also displayed.

shortdesc.p: Side-by-side comparison can be made between a test result and a baseline result. Both results must be for the same test module or test module variation.

shortdesc.p: The Result comparison page which is available on a web browser displays the differences, side-by-side, between two test results at checkpoints defined in the test procedure.

topic.title: Receiving test results of remote test execution

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect allows you to execute a test remotely and receive the test results from the remote machine, although TestArchitect Client is closed on the local machine, even before the remote execution is complete.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect test results may be opened in a web browser on any machine. TestArchitect need not be installed to view the results.

shortdesc.p: The TestArchitect command line tool is a Java program that enables you carry out some directives on TestArchitect.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The TestArchitect command line tool is a Java program that enables you carry out some directives on TestArchitect.

shortdesc.p: ta delete is used to remove local test results from the command-line interface.

topicmeta.shortdesc: ta delete is used to remove local test results from the command-line interface.

shortdesc.p: ta execute is used to execute tests from the command-line interface.

topicmeta.shortdesc: ta execute is used to execute tests from the command-line interface.

shortdesc.p: ta export is used to export Test Architect items such as repository, project, test folder, built-in actions, interface entities, test modules/test cases using the command-line interface.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect's dashboard tool allows you to create a wide range of reports and provides you with the dashboard tool to help you manage and monitor your projects.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect's dashboard tool allows you to create a wide range of reports and provides you with the dashboard tool to help you manage and monitor your projects.

shortdesc.p: With TestArchitect's powerful reporting features, customized reports can be generated to show current and historical data based on the various criteria that you specify. You can readily show the progress of test development, test run performance and result trends, and a host of other aspects of a project.

topicmeta.shortdesc: With TestArchitect's powerful reporting features, customized reports can be generated to show current and historical data based on the various criteria that you specify. You can readily show the progress of test development, test run performance and result trends, and a host of other aspects of a project.

shortdesc.p: Reports can be produced for entire projects or for specified project items.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reports can be produced for entire projects or for specified project items.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitectoffers a wealth of features to allow you to create reports on your projects and tests, and customize those reports to meet your unique needs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitectoffers a wealth of features to allow you to create reports on your projects and tests, and customize those reports to meet your unique needs.

shortdesc.p: After setting up a customized report, you may want to save the settings you have created so that future reports with those same settings can be readily generated. TestArchitect makes this possible with report profiles.

topicmeta.shortdesc: After setting up a customized report, you may want to save the settings you have created so that future reports with those same settings can be readily generated. TestArchitect makes this possible with report profiles.

shortdesc.p: This section describes concepts of TestArchitect's Dashboard and shows you how to use the Dashboard to support your testing tasks, track progress and display results.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section describes concepts of TestArchitect's Dashboard and shows you how to use the Dashboard to support your testing tasks, track progress and display results.

shortdesc.p: The TestArchitect Dashboard is a web–based application that connects directly to a TestArchitect repository and receives project information from it. This information can be presented as customizable graphs, charts, indicators, and reports to help you analyze and manage test projects.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The TestArchitect Dashboard is a web–based application that connects directly to a TestArchitect repository and receives project information from it. This information can be presented as customizable graphs, charts, indicators, and reports to help you analyze and manage test projects.

shortdesc.p: A Dashboard instance is accessible from TestArchitect Client, TestArchitect Lab Manager, or a browser.

topic.title: Optimizing JVM parameters for TestArchitect performance

shortdesc.p: Java Virtual Machine (JVM) heap memory size can be expanded and shrink, according to your requirements for TestArchitect's performance optimization. MaxHeapFreeRatio and MinHeapFreeRatio are the command line options available for this purpose in Oracle Java.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect's technology is based on a methodology called Action Based Testing (ABT). This chapter provides an introduction to ABT, which can be used for any type of testing, but has demonstrated its greatest benefit in automated testing.

shortdesc.p: Scripting, or programming, commonly refers to a process in which test cases are first developed by testers, usually in verbal form, and then automated, usually by a specialized automation engineer.

shortdesc.p: A replication repository is a mirror copy of a primary repository. Data between a replication repository and its designated primary repository are automatically synchronized and maintained.

topic.title: Invoking the Manage Users dialog box

shortdesc.p: The Manage Users dialog box can be used to add or delete users to or from a repository, edit their data, or change their assignments (permissions). You can also use the dialog box to change the password of a selected user, but this is only recommended if the user has forgotten his or her password and you need to reset it. It can also be used to assign the user to specific projects as a member of different functional groups, thus setting his or her functional permissions.

shortdesc.p: Using Tool Profiles, you can configure TestArchitect to support integration with external third-party tools. In addition, its support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on. Finally, Tool Profiles includes several predefined harnesses, which are scripts or programs that interpret and execute the action lines of a test sequence.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Using Tool Profiles, you can configure TestArchitect to support integration with external third-party tools. In addition, its support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on. Finally, Tool Profiles includes several predefined harnesses, which are scripts or programs that interpret and execute the action lines of a test sequence.

shortdesc.p: Many third-party sources offer tools that provide features which complement the functionality of TestArchitectin some way. The External tool offers a way for TestArchitect to integrate with those tools.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Many third-party sources offer tools that provide features which complement the functionality of TestArchitectin some way. The External tool offers a way for TestArchitect to integrate with those tools.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect can be integrated with issue tracking systems, enabling you and your team to easily monitor and update the status of bug issues by associating them with TestArchitect bugs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect can be integrated with issue tracking systems, enabling you and your team to easily monitor and update the status of bug issues by associating them with TestArchitect bugs.

shortdesc.p: Integration solutions are available for various third-party test management systems, offering you the option to harness the full potential of TestArchitect along with other systems to best meet your organization's particular needs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Integration solutions are available for various third-party test management systems, offering you the option to harness the full potential of TestArchitect along with other systems to best meet your organization's particular needs.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect's support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect's support for LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) allows your TestArchitect login credentials to be established through your system account, avoiding the need for a separate sign on.

shortdesc.p: The Test Tool node of the TestArchitect explorer tree provides several predefined harnesses, which are scripts or programs that interpret and execute the action lines of a test sequence. It also offers you the option of configuring your own harness, one designed for the programming language of your choice.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Test Tool node of the TestArchitect explorer tree provides several predefined harnesses, which are scripts or programs that interpret and execute the action lines of a test sequence. It also offers you the option of configuring your own harness, one designed for the programming language of your choice.

shortdesc.p: In order to run your test automation with a customized harness program, a test tool profile for that harness must be created.

shortdesc.p: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

shortdesc.p: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

shortdesc.p: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

shortdesc.p: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

shortdesc.p: After a 72-hour period of continuous operation following the failure or absence of a primary license server, a redundant license server blocks further requests for licenses. If your primary server remains unavailable, send an activation key request to LogiGear for an extension of the redundant server's operation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: After a 72-hour period of continuous operation following the failure or absence of a primary license server, a redundant license server blocks further requests for licenses. shortdesc.p: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

shortdesc.p: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

shortdesc.p: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

shortdesc.p: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

shortdesc.p: After a 72-hour period of continuous operation following the failure or absence of a primary license server, a redundant license server blocks further requests for licenses. If your primary server remains unavailable, send an activation key request to LogiGear for an extension of the redundant server's operation.

shortdesc.p: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A TestArchitect license server can be configured as a single server, one of multiple licensing servers, or as a redundant server.

shortdesc.p: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A single license server handles and grants licensing requests from TestArchitect Clients or controllers on your network.

shortdesc.p: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Host-based licensing is appropriate when it is unacceptable for a host to be denied a license from the license server. Host-based licensing allows a host to receive a license even when the pool of available floating licenses has been exhausted.

shortdesc.p: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Several license servers can be used to administer licenses to clients. For example, one license server may handle only agent licensing, while another dedicated license server may administer full client/controller licensing.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server operates in a network in tandem with another server designated as the main, or primary, license server. Redundant license servers assume the role of administering licenses when the primary server is offline or unable to administer licenses.

shortdesc.p: You can change the connection port on which a license server listens and grants license connection requests.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can change the connection port on which a license server listens and grants license connection requests.

shortdesc.p: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A redundant license server can be set up as a backup for an existing license server. When your primary license server goes down, the redundant license server is automatically and seamlessly activated.

shortdesc.p: After a 72-hour period of continuous operation following the failure or absence of a primary license server, a redundant license server blocks further requests for licenses. If your primary server remains unavailable, send an activation key request to LogiGear for an extension of the redundant server's operation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: After a 72-hour period of continuous operation following the failure or absence of a primary license server, a redundant license server blocks further requests for licenses. topic.title: Converting a floating license into a host-based license

shortdesc.p: Any floating license can be reconfigured to act as a host-based license, thereby restricting that license's availability to one specific machine.

topicmeta.linktext: Converting a floating license into a host-based license
topicmeta.shortdesc: Any floating license can be reconfigured to act as a host-based license, thereby restricting that license's availability to one specific machine.

topic.title: Converting a host-based license into a floating license

shortdesc.p: Any host-based license can be reconfigured to act as a floating license, thereby freeing that license from a specific machine.

topicmeta.navtitle: Converting a host-based license into a floating license
topicmeta.linktext: Converting a host-based license into a floating license
topicmeta.shortdesc: Any host-based license can be reconfigured to act as a floating license, thereby freeing that license from a specific machine.

shortdesc.p: A node-locked license is tied to a specific machine for a certain period of time, but, within some constraints, may be reassigned.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A node-locked license is tied to a specific machine for a certain period of time, but, within some constraints, may be reassigned.

shortdesc.p: Assigning a node-locked license binds that license to a machine for a given period of time.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Assigning a node-locked license binds that license to a machine for a given period of time.

shortdesc.p: Within certain limits, you are free to transfer a node-locked license from one machine to another, as you might wish to do when upgrading to a new test machine.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Within certain limits, you are free to transfer a node-locked license from one machine to another, as you might wish to do when upgrading to a new test machine.

topic.title: Upgrading node-locked into floating license keys

shortdesc.p: Node locked license keys by convention are not convertible into floating license keys. However, it is possible to upgrade node-locked into floating license keys, when you request a new upgrade key from LogiGear sales representative.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Obtaining a TestArchitect license is a two-step process that involves submitting a request to LogiGear for a license key and then using the key to add the license.

shortdesc.p: License keys can be requested from TestArchitect sales or a LogiGear representative using the Request TestArchitect Licenses dialog box.

topicmeta.shortdesc: License keys can be requested from TestArchitect sales or a LogiGear representative using the Request TestArchitect Licenses dialog box.

shortdesc.p: New license keys received from the LogiGear sales team may be added to your license server from the License Server Control Panel.

topicmeta.shortdesc: New license keys received from the LogiGear sales team may be added to your license server from the License Server Control Panel.

shortdesc.p: This section illustrates steps for starting and stopping the license server, and for changing the server port.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section illustrates steps for starting and stopping the license server, and for changing the server port.

topic.title: Starting and Stopping the license server

shortdesc.p: The license server can be started and stopped from the License Server Control Panel.

topicmeta.navtitle: Starting and Stopping the license server
topicmeta.linktext: Starting and Stopping the license server
topicmeta.shortdesc: The license server can be started and stopped from the License Server Control Panel.

shortdesc.p: You can change the connection port on which a license server listens and grants license connection requests.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can change the connection port on which a license server listens and grants license connection requests.

shortdesc.p: This section describes processes for reclaiming and removing licenses.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section describes processes for reclaiming and removing licenses.

topic.title: Reclaiming a floating license from a host

shortdesc.p: It may sometimes be necessary to reclaim a floating license from a host and return the license to the license pool.

topicmeta.navtitle: Reclaiming a floating license from a host
topicmeta.linktext: Reclaiming a floating license from a host
topicmeta.shortdesc: It may sometimes be necessary to reclaim a floating license from a host and return the license to the license pool.

shortdesc.p: Floating licenses can be removed from from the license server. This is useful for clearing out expired licenses

topicmeta.shortdesc: Floating licenses can be removed from from the license server. This is useful for clearing out expired licenses

shortdesc.p: This chapter involves connection establishment among TestArchitect components.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This chapter involves connection establishment among TestArchitect components.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect allows you to set the number of attempts for a failed connection which a TA component establishes to another component. For example, the TestArchitect Controller connects to a TestArchitect repository.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect allows you to set the number of attempts for a failed connection which a TA component establishes to another component. For example, the TestArchitect Controller connects to a TestArchitect repository.

shortdesc.p: With TestArchitect, you can test apps running on various environments, such as, desktop, web, mobile applications, etc.

topicmeta.shortdesc: With TestArchitect, you can test apps running on various environments, such as, desktop, web, mobile applications, etc.

shortdesc.p: Action Based Testing (ABT) is usually considered to be an automation technique. It is commonly positioned as an advanced and practical alternative to other techniques like "record & playback" or "scripting". Much about ABT is discussed in the following pages.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Action Based Testing (ABT) is usually considered to be an automation technique. It is commonly positioned as an advanced and practical alternative to other techniques like "record & playback" or "scripting". Much about ABT is discussed in the following pages.

shortdesc.p: Most tests consist of a sequence of action lines, with their action keywords and arguments. Actions are available as built-in actions, or can be created as user actions, implemented either with action definitions or programmed in an automation harness.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Most tests consist of a sequence of action lines, with their action keywords and arguments. Actions are available as built-in actions, or can be created as user actions, implemented either with action definitions or programmed in an automation harness.

shortdesc.p: Variables are placeholders that contain values for later use in one or more action lines, and which allow for easy substitution of values within given action lines.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Variables are placeholders that contain values for later use in one or more action lines, and which allow for easy substitution of values within given action lines.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Rules that must be observed when naming variables.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect 7.2 2.1 maintains support for the set variable action.

shortdesc.p: An expression is any combination of literal values, variables, operators, and functions that follows a set of rules, and which needs to be evaluated before it can be used.

topicmeta.shortdesc: An expression is any combination of literal values, variables, operators, and functions that follows a set of rules, and which needs to be evaluated before it can be used.

shortdesc.p: Actions can be written to return values to test modules or actions that call them.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Actions can be written to return values to test modules or actions that call them.

shortdesc.p: Functions are prewritten operations which you can reference by name within your expressions to produce values needed by your test.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Functions are prewritten operations which you can reference by name within your expressions to produce values needed by your test.

shortdesc.p: Control flow actions let you change the order in which action lines are executed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Control flow actions let you change the order in which action lines are executed.

shortdesc.p: Operator precedence determines the order in which operators are evaluated in TestArchitect. Operators with higher precedence are evaluated first.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Operator precedence determines the order in which operators are evaluated in TestArchitect. Operators with higher precedence are evaluated first.

shortdesc.p: In TestArchitect, a check compares and verifies expected behavior against actual observed behavior during a test. It's good practice to incorporate checks in test procedures to verify that the procedures are running as expected.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In TestArchitect, a check compares and verifies expected behavior against actual observed behavior during a test. It's good practice to incorporate checks in test procedures to verify that the procedures are running as expected.

shortdesc.p: Handling unanticipated errors, warnings or test failures.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Handling unanticipated errors, warnings or test failures.

shortdesc.p: Use the set notice level action to specify the types of problem-related messages that are inhibited from being displayed during the test run.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Use the set notice level action to specify the types of problem-related messages that are inhibited from being displayed during the test run.

shortdesc.p: You can direct TestArchitect to escape from the current flow of the test when an error occurs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can direct TestArchitect to escape from the current flow of the test when an error occurs.

shortdesc.p: You can provide TestArchitect with specific instructions as to what to do when a problem occurs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can provide TestArchitect with specific instructions as to what to do when a problem occurs.

shortdesc.p: Error and failure handlers can be made more flexible by having them accept arguments.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Error and failure handlers can be made more flexible by having them accept arguments.

shortdesc.p: Successful testing requires that the automation correctly handle the varying response times of a system under test, and not to attempt to continue with interactions before the system is finished with the previous function.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Successful testing requires that the automation correctly handle the varying response times of a system under test, and not to attempt to continue with interactions before the system is finished with the previous function.

title.strong: Understanding action types and condition types

shortdesc.p: For a full understanding of timing settings and their effects, it is helpful to understand the types of UI-related action, and the two types of UI-testing conditions.

navtitle.b: Understanding action types and condition types

topicmeta.linktext: Understanding action types and condition types
topicmeta.shortdesc: For a full understanding of timing settings and their effects, it is helpful to understand the types of UI-related action, and the two types of UI-testing conditions.

shortdesc.p: Timing settings used for a given action are largely determined by the type of action it is. Actions that interact with the AUT can be classified into UI-testing and UI-interfacing actions. Each group can be further classified into subgroups.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Timing settings used for a given action are largely determined by the type of action it is. Actions that interact with the AUT can be classified into UI-testing and UI-interfacing actions. Each group can be further classified into subgroups.

shortdesc.p: The execution of an action may involve one or more UI-related tests that must be satisfied before the primary function of the action can be executed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The execution of an action may involve one or more UI-related tests that must be satisfied before the primary function of the action can be executed.

shortdesc.p: Timing settings can be roughly broken down into two types: critical and non-critical.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Timing settings can be roughly broken down into two types: critical and non-critical.

shortdesc.p: The critical wait settings (window wait, page wait, object wait, item wait and property wait) are those which are used for conditions and preconditions which, if not satisfied, result in a warning or failing of a test.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The critical wait settings ( window wait, page wait, object wait, item wait and property wait) are those which are used for conditions and preconditions which, if not satisfied, result in a warning or failing of a test.

shortdesc.p: Non-critical wait settings (window wait probe, object wait probe, and value changed wait) are not associated with interruptions of normal program flow.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Non-critical wait settings ( window wait probe, object wait probe, and value changed wait) are not associated with interruptions of normal program flow.

shortdesc.p: window wait probe and object wait probe are used for non-critical condition tests.

topicmeta.shortdesc: window wait probe and object wait probe are used for non-critical condition tests.

shortdesc.p: The value changed wait setting is concerned with the delays that may be incurred in the changing of a value or state in the AUT's interface after a UI-modifying action has executed.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The value changed wait setting is concerned with the delays that may be incurred in the changing of a value or state in the AUT's interface after a UI-modifying action has executed.

shortdesc.p: A summary of the relationship between timing settings, action types, and associated conditions and preconditions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: A summary of the relationship between timing settings, action types, and associated conditions and preconditions.

shortdesc.p: At any stage of an action that tests for the presence of a given UI element, a wait may be imposed while the automation continuously samples for that element. It is important to know, based on the action type, the conditions that cause the wait to occur, and those that end it.

topicmeta.shortdesc: At any stage of an action that tests for the presence of a given UI element, a wait may be imposed while the automation continuously samples for that element. It is important to know, based on the action type, the conditions that cause the wait to occur, and those that end it.

topic.title: Summary of action types and timing settings

shortdesc.p: Summary of timing settings and how they interact with actions.

topicmeta.navtitle: Summary of action types and timing settings
topicmeta.linktext: Summary of action types and timing settings
topicmeta.shortdesc: Summary of timing settings and how they interact with actions.

shortdesc.p: When the ignore modifier (the string “ignore”, surrounded by angle brackets) is used as an argument value in supported actions, TestArchitect bypasses that action during test execution and continues at the subsequent action line.

topicmeta.shortdesc: When the ignore modifier (the string ignore, surrounded by angle brackets) is used as an argument value in supported actions, TestArchitect bypasses that action during test execution and continues at the subsequent action line.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect offers you two methods for verifying the correctness of images produced by a tested application: pixel-by-pixel comparison and keypoint detection.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect offers you two methods for verifying the correctness of images produced by a tested application: pixel-by-pixel comparison and keypoint detection.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect offers you two methods for recognizing text produced by an AUT: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Graphics Device Interface (GDI) techniques.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect offers you two methods for recognizing text produced by an AUT: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Graphics Device Interface (GDI) techniques.

shortdesc.p: You can set a timeout for the test case to ensure that the test execution does not take longer than it should.

topicmeta.shortdesc: You can set a timeout for the test case to ensure that the test execution does not take longer than it should.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect includes a library of built-in actions to perform a myriad of functions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect includes a library of built-in actions to perform a myriad of functions.

shortdesc.p: System built-in actions include those which allow your test to interact with the host operating system of your test automation, and perform other miscellaneous functions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: System built-in actions include those which allow your test to interact with the host operating system of your test automation, and perform other miscellaneous functions.

shortdesc.p: Clipboard built-in actions include those actions which allow your test to interact with the short-term data storage of the host system clipboard.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Clipboard built-in actions include those actions which allow your test to interact with the short-term data storage of the host system clipboard.

shortdesc.p: Command line actions are those built-in actions which interact with the host computer's operating system through the command line interface (CLI).

topicmeta.shortdesc: Command line actions are those built-in actions which interact with the host computer's operating system through the command line interface (CLI).

shortdesc.p: This section includes built-in actions that connect to and run queries on database management systems (DBMSs) or Microsoft Excel data sources.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section includes built-in actions that connect to and run queries on database management systems (DBMSs) or Microsoft Excel data sources.

shortdesc.p: Device built-in actions communicate with mobile devices attached to your test machines.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Device built-in actions communicate with mobile devices attached to your test machines.

shortdesc.p: File and folder built-in actions provide a comprehensive way to work with text files, and folders.

topicmeta.shortdesc: File and folder built-in actions provide a comprehensive way to work with text files, and folders.

shortdesc.p: This section contains information on JSON automation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section contains information on JSON automation.

shortdesc.p: This category consists of a single built-in action, type, which can simulate the pressing of keys such as Enter, Spacebar, Backspace, all arrow keys, and function keys ( F1, F2, etc.), as well as key combinations.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This category consists of a single built-in action, type, which can simulate the pressing of keys such as Enter, Spacebar, Backspace, all arrow keys, and function keys ( F1, F2, etc.), as well as key combinations.

shortdesc.p: Mouse built-in actions are used to mimic mouse events, such as clicks, moves, and drags.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Mouse built-in actions are used to mimic mouse events , such as clicks, moves, and drags.

shortdesc.p: Operating system built-in actions help you monitor and interact with desktop or mobile operating systems on your test machine(s).

topicmeta.shortdesc: Operating system built-in actions help you monitor and interact with desktop or mobile operating systems on your test machine(s).

shortdesc.p: This section contains information on XML automation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: This section contains information on XML automation.

shortdesc.p: Web services are specific applications that can be published and called over the Internet by client applications. This section includes built-in actions that support functional testing of web services.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Web services are specific applications that can be published and called over the Internet by client applications. This section includes built-in actions that support functional testing of web services.

shortdesc.p: The Test Support category of built-in actions includes those actions which perform execution control, test resource declaration, test documentation, and reporting.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The Test Support category of built-in actions includes those actions which perform execution control, test resource declaration, test documentation, and reporting.

shortdesc.p: Action Definition built-in actions help you to define arguments in user-defined actions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Action Definition built-in actions help you to define arguments in user-defined actions.

shortdesc.p: Control Flow built-in actions break up the flow of execution by employing decision making, looping, and branching, enabling your test to run conditionally-executed blocks of action lines.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Control Flow built-in actions break up the flow of execution by employing decision making, looping, and branching, enabling your test to run conditionally-executed blocks of action lines.

shortdesc.p: Data set built-in actions help you to define and use data sets and filters.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Data set built-in actions help you to define and use data sets and filters.

shortdesc.p: Deprecated built-in actions include those actions which should be avoided, typically because they have been superseded.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Deprecated built-in actions include those actions which should be avoided, typically because they have been superseded.

shortdesc.p: Documentary built-in actions perform test documentation and assist in properly organizing your test module, which aids in ensuring conformance to the ABT methodology.

shortdesc.p: Interface Handling built-in actions allow you to create interfaces, interface entities, interface elements and use them in your test procedures.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Interface Handling built-in actions allow you to create interfaces, interface entities, interface elements and use them in your test procedures.

shortdesc.p: Remote Agents built-in actions handle the connection between lead controller machines and deputy controller machines in remote test execution.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Remote Agents built-in actions handle the connection between lead controller machines and deputy controller machines in remote test execution.

shortdesc.p: Reporting and Formatting built-in actions convert internal data inside your test procedures into formatted output.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reporting and Formatting built-in actions convert internal data inside your test procedures into formatted output.

shortdesc.p: Timing built-in actions handle the varying response times of an application under test. It is important that tests not sample AUT outputs faster than the AUT can respond to stimuli, which can cause false failures. At the same time, tests should wait no longer than necessary for functions to complete, because excessive waits can slow down overall run times of large test runs.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Timing built-in actions handle the varying response times of an application under test. It is important that tests not sample AUT outputs faster than the AUT can respond to stimuli, which can cause false failures. At the same time, tests should wait no longer than necessary for functions to complete, because excessive waits can slow down overall run times of large test runs.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect has a number of built-in settings that control various runtime behaviors of TestArchitect.

shortdesc.p: Setting functions that operate on timing are classified as timing settings. They include functions for handling timing issues arising when window or web pages take an unexpected amount of time to display (from the point of view of the automation).

topicmeta.shortdesc: Setting functions that operate on timing are classified as timing settings. They include functions for handling timing issues arising when window or web pages take an unexpected amount of time to display (from the point of view of the automation).

shortdesc.p: Built-in settings that operate on displayed values are classified as value settings. They include functions for ignoring case sensitivity in string comparison, trimming white spaces from the beginnings and ends of strings, etc.

shortdesc.p: A hodge-podge of built-in settings that don't fit into any other categories. Includes settings for loading visible controls, setting the default web browser, etc.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect offers a number of built-in actions and automation methods that allow for tests to connect to, and query, SQL-compliant databases. This allows for an expanded form of data-driven testing beyond that which relies on TestArchitect's proprietary data sets. It also expands the possibilities for performing tests on database-dependent applications. This topic presents a few of the typical test configurations involving SQL-based databases, along with specific examples.

This topic presents a few of the typical test configurations involving SQL-based databases, along with specific examples.

shortdesc.p: Information specific to Silverlight application testing.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Information specific to Silverlight application testing.

shortdesc.p: TestArchitect provides full support for automated testing of applications based on Microsoft Silverlight technology.

topicmeta.shortdesc: TestArchitect provides full support for automated testing of applications based on Microsoft Silverlight technology.

shortdesc.p: Silverlight applications are rich internet applications (RIAs) which are executed in web browsers. In-browser mode is the most common way to use them.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Silverlight applications are rich internet applications (RIAs) which are executed in web browsers. In-browser mode is the most common way to use them.

shortdesc.p: In order to test a Silverlight application, you need to properly configure your test environment. This may include preparing a web browser's settings, installing a Certificate Authority, and possibly other actions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In order to test a Silverlight application, you need to properly configure your test environment. This may include preparing a web browser's settings, installing a Certificate Authority, and possibly other actions.

shortdesc.p: To allow TestArchitect to work properly with a Silverlight application embedded into a web page, you may need to prepare your web browser.

topicmeta.linktext: Preparing a web browser for testing Silverlight applications
topicmeta.shortdesc: To allow TestArchitect to work properly with a Silverlight application embedded into a web page, you may need to prepare your web browser.

shortdesc.p: In order to test Silverlight applications running over the HTTPS protocol, installing a TestArchitect Certificate Authority (CA) on your test machine is required.

topicmeta.shortdesc: In order to test Silverlight applications running over the HTTPS protocol, installing a TestArchitect Certificate Authority (CA) on your test machine is required.

topic.title: Configuring a test machine for Silverlight

shortdesc.p: Preparing your test machine to ensure the testability of your Silverlight application.

topicmeta.navtitle: Configuring a test machine for Silverlight
topicmeta.linktext: Configuring a test machine for Silverlight
topicmeta.shortdesc: Preparing your test machine to ensure the testability of your Silverlight application.

shortdesc.p: Silverlight-based applications, as well as your test machine, must be configured properly to allow the applications to be installed from their host web pages, run outside of the browser, and tested.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Silverlight-based applications, as well as your test machine, must be configured properly to allow the applications to be installed from their host web pages, run outside of the browser, and tested.

shortdesc.p: Silverlight controls supported by TestArchitect for testing Silverlight applications.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Silverlight controls supported by TestArchitect for testing Silverlight applications.

shortdesc.p: If you no longer need to test Silverlight applications running over the HTTPS protocol, you may opt to uninstall the TestArchitect Certificate Authority (CA) which was previously installed.

topicmeta.shortdesc:
If you no longer need to test Silverlight applications running over the HTTPS protocol, you may opt to uninstall the
TestArchitect Certificate Authority (CA) which was previously installed.

shortdesc.p: If and when you no longer need to test Silverlight applications, it is highly recommended that you reset your machine's proxy server settings to make your web browsers work properly under normal conditions.

topicmeta.shortdesc: If and when you no longer need to test Silverlight applications, it is highly recommended that you reset your machine's proxy server settings to make your web browsers work properly under normal conditions.

shortdesc.p: Web services are applications that can be published and called over the Internet by client applications. TestArchitect supports functional testing of web services.

shortdesc.p: Functional testing of web services consists of invoking web service's APIs from TestArchitect's test procedures and checking the returned result values.

topicmeta.linktext: Testing web apps in mobile emulation mode
topicmeta.shortdesc: With TestArchitect, you can create and run automated tests for mobile web applications and websites without the need for real mobile devices, also known as agent-based automation testing.

shortdesc.p: Mobile web testing can be challenging and tedious, thanks to the large variety of mobile devices, platforms and screen sizes. TestArchitect addresses this challenge by letting you test mobile web applications on device emulators. Without the need for real physical devices of every type to ensure full testing coverage, your testing setup and maintenance is highly simplified.

topicmeta.linktext: Testing web apps in mobile emulation mode - Overview

TestArchitect addresses this challenge by letting you test mobile web applications on device emulators. Without the need for real physical devices of every type to ensure full testing coverage, your testing setup and maintenance is highly simplified.
